content:
y 29, 2015
												A well done action FPS game that seemed to slip through without being noticed by most people. Play as all 3 species, each with thier own story and goals. GameplayThe gameplay feels fluent and smooth. FPS drops were very few and far between on my medium end PC on high settings. You spend most of your time traversing through mostly linear levels completing objects along the way. In some areas objectives make you kill waves of enemies or solve puzzling problems such as figuring out how to enter a room, which helps keep that game a little more interesting rather than traveling through from place to place shooting everything in site. Where controls are concerned, each species plays differently with thier own style of movement and controls and some are better than others. Playing as the marines feels like your typical FPS game, basically shoot your way through the level with a variety of guns. You feel more vulnerable as a marine as well as Aliens are very quick and come in hordes, and predators are much more powerful. Playing as the Alien and Predator is where this game stands out from other FPS games. The predator has a variety of gadgets such as the laser cannon to fight from a distance as well as a spear and claws to tear your enemies to shreds up close. You are able to jump high and far using an ability, this allows the predators to have alot of verticality to combat. You can also go invisible to catch your enemies by surprise, however get to close and the humans with see through you camo. The Aliens are very quick and agile, while playing the Alien you are able to crawl up walls and leave very far. These contols are hard to get the hang of at first but once you get the hang of them you feel pretty deadly. You are quieter but all these perks come with a price, and that is your health. As the alien you will need to learn to be stealthy on your approach to clear rooms as well as know when to run and hide. Both of these species have special instant kill stealth moves and grab kills, however for as cool as they look, they also leave you very vulnerable to attack, their is also no way of cancelling this action and they take a few seconds to finish. If you are attacked during thease few seconds you will most likely die or barely get away.GraphicsOn high the graphics looked really good, they felt like real areas and fit the setting of the Alien/Predator universe. The levels are pretty well designed, and their is a variety of settings to traverse through as you go through the story such as the forest, ruins, structures and a few others. The gun fire flash looks good in dark rooms and the lighting is done very well adding to the spooky theme of some areas. The design and animation of the Aliens and Predators look well designed and look like their movie counterparts. The animation looks good, especially the Alien looks like it had a lot of work done to it to make it look and move realistically as it crawls over the walls. The animations during the stealth/grab kills are very well done and look badass and gory the way they should be in this style of game. AudioThe audio is decent, although some of the guns sounded terrible and wimpy. The sound design during the levels does a pretty good job of making you feel on edge and adds a little bit to the suspense. The aliens sounded like the aliens from the movies however nothing special, same with the predator, you hear his significant and unique sounds but its nothing really special or new. The marines are terribly voice acted and their likes sounds cheasy. For the most part the audio is decent and will add to the feel of the setting but nothing special.StoryThe story are different and each species has their own goal in mind however their is crossover between each story. As a marine you are trying to fight back the Aliens and find out what happened after a problem occurs in a research facility your goal is to find out what happened, where they are coming from, and how to stop it, but end up crossing paths with the predator down the line changing some of your objectives. The Alien story line has you playing an Alien captured by humans and tested on. When the queen calls you seek to find her, only to be restrained by the humans, however after an issue arises during an experiment you are able to break the shackles that bind you down, allowing you to fight back, escape, and find your queen to learn why she is calling you.The Predator story arc has you playing as a predator needing to prove himself to the elders to earn his right to be a hunter. This has you traveling through multipul areas killing Aliens in trials from the elders, through your trials you will cross paths with the marines leading for some objectives to become skewed as you destroy the resistance.SummaryAliens vs. Predator is a decent FPS action game that goes off the path from your basic FPS game. Being able to play as all 3 species with thier own unique abilities, movements and story arcs is fun and helps the game feel fresh. The story is decent, with some being better than others. They did a good job of balancing the characters out with thier own advantages and weaknesses making each species feel like it should. The world looks good and well designed. The controls feel good and tight, the only one that took a while to get used to was the aliens movements because of its quick pace and ability to climb on walls and other surfaces.This is a good game that would be good to get on sale. Fans of first person shooters may enjoy the originality of playing as all 3 characters in this game, however if you are looking for a horror game, this may not be it. While it seems to try to be one, it doesnt seem to commit to the idea as the game progresses, at most this game may hit the creepy feeling at some points but thats about it.I can not comment on the multiplayer as I never tried it myself, but for the most part from what I've heard is that its fun but almost always dead. So maybe with a few friends it could be fun for a get together.

												Iâm not sure whether this game is honestly enjoyable or if my expectations going into it were were so low that I was able to enjoy it. The story is based around 3 campaigns(that may or may not be interlocking, some parts seem that way while others donât), one for each race and each with their own separate playstyles. The human campaign started out really creepy, like something taken straight out of Alien, but then quickly became a really fun shooter but whoever decided to add a thump sound to the radar is dumb.  The alien campaign was the least enjoyable of the 3, in theory it should have been really fun because it has you climbing up walls and running on the roof but it is really disorienting. The predator campaign was also enjoyable but the stealth elements were pretty much useless so good thing the melee combat was enjoyable. It flirts with outstaying its welcome and it is almost too tedious but it ends at a good point and itâs not too dragged out. Overall I feel like this was a fun game, nothing amazing or anything but enjoyable.

content:
17, 2013
												For a FPS, this game is actually quite long. It takes an average 14 to 17 hours of gameplay to finish it as you play through 3 different types of entities. The enemy AI is really great and sometimes even challenging in certains parts of the game even in normal difficulty. You can play in which ever order and each one gives you a slightly different experience.As the Marnie, the game takes the traditional route like any FPS with you typical arsenal of weapons but with a survival horror twist. When playing, you really got to be on your toes and stay alert as the xenomorphs can pop out of nowhere.As the Alien, the game shifts to a 1st person stealth game as you lurk through vents and pick off the enemy one by one. Stealth is the key and the darkness is your friend. To regain health as the Alien, you must devour your prey. Playing the Alien is my personal favorite.As the Predator, the game is a mix of stealth and the ability to use your wide varity of gadgets with a touch of brute strenght. The predator is the more powerful of the 3, but however don't get too cocky. Predators can be killed too. To regain health for the Predator, he uses a gadget in his arsenal with also drains power. Just remember, electric weapons such as the blaster and should cannon use power.The game's story is not as great as the previous two Aliens vs Predator games and at times can be murky but it makes up for it in the gameplay. If you are a Aliens vs Predator fan, you will not be disappointed as it stays true to the Aliens vs Predator lure. I rate this a 8/10.If you know know nothing about Aliens vs Predator than this game could look average to the casual FPS gamer and may come on as a 6/10.

y 12, 2014
												Aliens vs Predator is a great game based on the Unreal Engine 3 focused on 3 main parts, 2 of them are 2 different types of stealth action and 1 survival horror (the marines, aliens and predators respectively). The game is always in the first person view, making it highly realistic but a bit confusing when running on walls and it takes some getting used to.The sounds are highly emersive and very realistic, adding to the atmosphere of the game.The graphics are very good (as already mentioned the game is based on the unreal engine 3 , so there isn't really a way to could look bad anyway ), naturally I found one or two places where the textures glitch out but those are random spots on the terrain where the majority of players wouldn't probably visit.The gameplay is solid, the Marines campaign gets a bit tiring since it's pretty much a lot of the same. The aliens campaign is the best however the shortest, (you can't have your cake and eat it too) the predators campaign however kind of doesn't fit in... What I mean by that is that the entire battle between the aliens and humans doesn't really leave much space for the the predators story to develop, but then again I'm just nit-picking at a really solid title.

content:
y 26, 2014
												This game is a hell of a lot of fun, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.  You just have to make peace with its flaws.Like in previous AvP games, the campaign is split into three parallel mini-campaigns, which intertwine in a fun and interesting way, allowing each species to use common elements of the setting's colonies and ruins in different ways for different purposes, and to different ends.  This may end up dissapointing some who will see the campaign as lazily reusing map assets so they don't have to tailor make levels for each character, but I find this complaint falls flat.  The level design smartly builds a unique playing space for each of the game's three species in each game level, something which must have taken much deliberation and iteration, whether or not you agree with the design decision.  Each storyline is really successful in acheiving a different feel and imparting a unique importance to each character;  The marine campaign is a terrifying account of a human just trying to stumble his way through this whole mess alive, the Predator campaign is full of bravado, badassitude, and honor, and the Alien campaign is all about essentially trolling the other two species in a deadly way and undermining everything anyone else is trying to acheive.  Of the three, the Alien's campaign is easily the weakest, although there is still a lot of fun to be had terrifying marines and pinning scientists to the ground for facehugger implantation.The campaigns themselves are surpisingly challenging, though short.  I found that the difficulty of the singleplayer game is mostly fair, harshly punishing stupid mistakes, though your mileage may vary.  A huge part of the game is a keen awareness of your own limitations as a human, Alien, or Predator, and also a smart but controlled exploitation of your own advantages, leading to an experience that can get surpisingly cerebral for what otherwise presents itself as a big, dumb action game (and the story IS big and dumb). The checkpoint system in single player is bizarre and terrible, unfortunately.  This meshes incredibly poorly with how difficult the game can get, leading to moments I just wanted to give up and walk away from the entire game. Ultimately, on the single player side of things, expect a dissapointingly short, dumbly written, but absolutely exciting and relatively unique (at least, in this day and age) romp through the built up mythos of all three species.Multiplayer, unfortunately, is a bit of a mixed bag.  At the best of times, Alien vs Predator's multiplayer is just huge loads of fun.  It's action packed one moment, tensely silent another, and totally empowering the next, just before you realize you're outgunnned or outnumbered and you start running away from other players in terror.  Unfortunately, people's complaints about rampant stupid garbage in multiplayer are SPOT ON ACCURATE.  The different deathmatch modes highlight this game's unfun nonsense way more often than other, more mechanically interesting and unique game modes; unfortunately, TDM is far and away the most popular game mode, drawing in players for its simplicity and action.  Be prepared to scream impotently at your computer as you, a slavering, 7 foot horror from outer space leap at a hapless marine from across the room, only to bounce off and land stunned on the ground as if the guy were made out of steel and bolted to the floor, simply because he saw you or heard you and blocked.  Prepare to occasionally see marines beating predators and aliens in melee combat.  Prepare for plasmacasters still being rage inducing, even 13 years after AvP2.  Prepare, even, for a stealth kill mechanic that encourages players to just run circles around each other to see who can get enough of a glimpse of another player's back to hit the "E" key and get an easy instakill.  At this point in the game's life,  players are obliged to play by their own made up rules about when it's okay to get an "E kill" or when weapons like the plasmacaster are permitted.The matchmaking, additionally, is absolutely terrible (although there is a server browser), and at this point in time there are very few players, making it a chore to find a game running, let alone a game running something more interesting than Team Death Match.That all being said, when you can get a good game going, the game is really good.  Even through multiplayer's bull, fun shines through.  The Hunt mode from AvP2 returns as Predator Hunt, featuring one Predator vs a team of marines, and is excellent and very evocative of the movies.  The Infestation mode is somewhat similar in set up; the entire team starts as marines, and one of them is chosen randomly to spawn as an alien.  When the alien kills a marine player, the killed player switches sides and joind the aliens, and this continues until the dwindling human group survives for long enough or is wiped out.  Aliens vs Predator also features its own co-op horde mode, Survivor, where marine players take on waves of alien bots. While tense and fun in its own right, Survivor is a bit too light on features compared to the horde modes of other games to really hold my attention.  These sit alongside the game's own point capture mode and three different rulesets for Deathmatch, adding up to a fairly large catalog of different ways to play.All in all, Aliens vs Predator got an unfair shake, I think.  Huge hype combined with mixed reviews to convince the public that the game was a middling cash in, when in actual fact I think that the developers put a lot of thought and heart into bringing back the mechanics of an old multiplayer classic while still trying to innovate.  A lot of the moves they made in production are clear missteps and there's no hiding that, but if you can accept or work past the game's obvous problems, there's quality fun to be had here, and the game certainly offers an experience that simply can't be had anywhere else.It's certainly more fun than Aliens: Colonial Marines, and manages to feel more authentic even with how much effort A:CM's team put into recreating environments and elements from the Aliens film.  I just wish AvP's Survivor mode was more like A:CM's Bug Hunt.

content:
6
												TIME TO COMPLETE: 12 hoursUnfortunately the game doesn't live up to its name and is only a castrated version of the franchise when compared to its predecesors.The campaigns themselves are very short with no more than 3-4 hours with each species. You'd think they'd make up in quality then but unfortunately that is not the case. Like I said the story is a very dumbed-down copy-pasted scenario fans of the extended universe will be familiar with and none of the characters could manage to be likable with all their generic traits the developers inherited them with. Not even the Marine protagonist could stand up as something more than an empty shell of a badass, black dude. The Predator has subtitles but not even those could help. It's quite laughable when you compare it to the silent descriptions of the two alien species from AvP2.Gameplay-wise it has been dumbed down a lot to accomodate for the consoles (and lazy programming, perhaps) with clunky controls and the inability of crouching - not that you would need it but it also shows how mediocre the level design is. My guess is that they had tried to modulate the gameplay but ultimately failed as it's either trophy kills which leave you vulnerable or good ol' stabbing which is not much good either. There's a decent story to go along with but not enough to hide the fact that it's a repetitive "start the generator", "enter lift for exposition" or "protect thing" sequence all over again. The campaigns are short so you might not see it at first but it truly becomes obvious when you move on to the next. The boss fights are not too intimidating either as the joke of "when in doubt, shoot" can be applied here.On a positive note the soundtrack is great and it fits quite well, adding some sense of drama or tension to certain moments. Too bad the rest of the story doesn't hold up to it.Overall it's an ok game if you enjoy the newer, dumbed down kind of FPS games but little dedication is seen to have been put into it. I never felt as if it were made by people who were genuinely interested rather than those who wanted to fully profit from it. Get it on sale if you are dying for more AvP stuff but don't expect much as it doesn't live up to what its predecessors have managed to deliver.

												Such a strange game, but truly a memory to remain. Offering a great approach to asymmetrical gameplay, AvP allows what few games will ever dare : True choice. Want to run and gun, CoD style? Humans for days.Got that freaky side that loves to tease your friends? Aliens â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ 'ery body out there.Are you the killjoy that your friends murmur about with sharp disgust? Yeah, Predator's know that feel. They got you.All in all, a diverse experience. Even if you don't care for multiplayer, then you still have the THREE campaigns to play. Each incredibly different, you'll get to enjoy your pick of a horror, action, or even a stealth-focused campaign. As a biased player, I still must beg you, my unfortunate reader, to truly consider the human campaign. It's like the Michael Bay's version of Alien: Isolation. You need this in your life. 9/10, would get dismembered/anally probed again.

content:
y 31, 2015
												As a fan of the Alien franchise as well as the Predator, I personally think this is a great game. This game puts you in the eyes of your favorite species: Xenomorph, Predator, and Colonial Marine, all with unique characteristics and abilites. Xenomorphs can traverse on walls  and sneak up on enemies only to tear their head off. Predators can go invisible for a short time and have thermal optics to better see enemies, slashing them to bits. And Marines, well.. they have guns. Being able to play as all 3 species puts a whole twist on the franchise, and allows people to finally realize what it feels like to be a bloodthirsty Predator. While this game is old, it is still a classic. My one and only complaint is that the campaign is rather short for all the species. You basically play for awhile completeling various objectives, fight a boss, then switch species. It can be over quick, but still very enjoyable. If you enjoy the movies, you'll love the game.

content:
ry 20, 2016
												This game is amazing! All the unique factions, weapons, skins, and gamemodes make this game an awesome fps!Single Player: The single player is a basic campaign mode. There are three different campaigns, each about 3 hours long. You can play the Alien campaign, Marine campaign, and Predator campaign. It's cool how all these stories are connected but with different perspectives.Multiplayer: The multiplayer is a standard fps online multiplayer. You can play as the 3 different factions, play all sorts of unique gamemodes, and level up to unlock skins for your factions. As a marine, you use guns and grenades to eliminate your enemies. The guns are a pulse rifle, pistol, shotgun, sniper rifle, flamethrower, smart gun, and rocket launcher. Playing as a marine is a basic fps basically. The Alien faction is a speedy faction which can climb up walls, go in vents, and do parkour. They use their tails, claws, and stealth takedowns to elimenate enemies. The Predator faction uses all sorts of weapons and gadgets. Spears, missile launchers, and razor blades. Predators can also cloak and use heat vision. It is pretty easy to find a server, and a decent amount of people play.Gameplay & Modes: The game is basically an fps. The factions are balanced with unique skills and skins. In the campaign, there are many stealth missions which you have to use stealth and takedowns to eliminate enemies. The modes are species TDM, TDM, DM, and Domination.Skins & Leveling Up: As you play AVP multiplayer, you will rank up depending on how good you do in a match. You gain xp by getting kills and doing awesome stuff, and the ranking system is basically just COD's ranking system. As you level up, you will unlock skins to make your characters look awesome. The max rank is 99. 10/10

content:
y 7, 2016
												First, while I admit this game isn't as close to being as good as the one developed in 2001 (AVP 2), it does have some perks, but I'd give this game a 7/10 for effort.Perks:1)  Great atmosphere, you will get some level of fear playing as the marine (which is where the main story is)2)  Predator and Alien campaigns are pretty well done, while adding depth to the species3)  Enjoy the limiting of the marine's weapons, requiring you to make valid and calculated choices.4)  Lance Henrickson . . . enough said5)  Fighting off an alien hive in an adult bar . . . epic and scary at the same time.5)  Being able to attack the Preds with a cohort of Xenomorphs.Flaws:1)  The melee combat for humans?  WTF is a pistol whip going to do against a Xeno or Pred about to shaft you?2)  Predalien that can hop through lava?  Come on, downing the queen early on was more plausible, as was the Praetorian.3)  Voice-less main character?  In this age of story-telling, having a silent protagonist is kinda lackluster to the product.4)  Doesn't seem to be enough fear and suspense in some areas for a game based on two classics of the same genre.So, while I give the game props for decent level design and graphics, along with some interesting play options . . . it's kinda lackluster for the series compared to the two originals.  I recommend this game to those who truly love the series or like the potential in the multiplayer . . . other than than, it's kind of a meh level thumbs up.

r 10, 2015
												played this game a long time ago along with AvP 2, and i didnt like it much back then.  played it again now, and i like it more now than back then.+ graphics, the level of detail in the design of the charecters and creatures is AMAZING.+ alien AI, it is simply the best alien AI to date; the way they move, the way they use the enviroment to sneak up on u and dodge ur shots.  i would say the alien AI here is even better than the more recent Alien isolation (ANOTHER FREAKIN AWESOME GAME)+ the predatore campain, the presentation of this particulare campain and how it runs is just great, makes u feel liek the hunter (as it should)+ the predalien+ sound design is fantastic, and the music is scripted nicely to fit the situations- the art style is meh on close inspection, and â¥â¥â¥â¥ that outline thing around the charecters.- predatore AI, the complete opposite of the alien AI, the predator AI is so bad to the point that the predator boss fight in the marin campain is too easy (i didnt get hit once FFS)- the marin campain, the marin story has always been imo the weak link of the games; tying down the alien and predator to the marin story line just limits the other 2 stories that have potential to much better and more supstantial if left un constained by the â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ humans.- the controls, this was wat made me hate this game back when it was new, the movement is stiff, the animations r heavily delayed and just...stiff.  everythign about it feels stiff and constraintive, as if this game was tryign to be more scrripted than free.- campain length, i finished the game in 6 hours.- predator weapons, where is the arsenal of weapons the predator had in the previous game? the â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ marin has more weapons here than the predator DA â¥â¥â¥.- the repetitve levels, u go thro the same 6? levels on the 3 campaigns and its dull near the end- the 3 story lines dont tie up satisfyingly as in AvP 2, by the end of my second playthrough im still not sure wither the predator campaign happens before, during, or after the marine.  its just confusing and ends up feeling without purpose in the end.over all, i love this game, but still like the previouse one a whole lot better.  and this one is good treatment for the horror stress of alien isolation, high recommend playing that first then playing this to give the aliens some much needed revenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
16, 2015
												Aliens vs Predator 3 is one of my all time favorite games. It is very under-rated. Ill give you a basic run down of the game.PREDATOR: He is my personal favorite. Movies and games,the predator is like the ultimate hunter. He is very powerful, when taking down marines this can require patience if there are mutiple of them. The predators advantages consist of his health, his weapons, and his claw speed. For his health he has the most health in the game. Him being the biggest one of the three this is not suprising. His weapons are godly poweful. He has four weapons. The campaign starts you with them in this order. Plasma caster, Mines, Smart disc, and Spear.  The plasma caster is a very powerful weapon. If you charge it long enough if it hits it is an automaic one hit. The plasma caster automatically predicts where youre target is going to go and fires there. The proximity mines are essentialey plasma clamores that detect in all directions. This is most effective against marines as they arent fast enough to escape one if they set it off. The smart disc, my favorite weapon, Is a edged disc that is guided by the laser on your mask when you throw it. It can bounce off of walls an absured amount of times and make the enemy â¥â¥â¥â¥ their pants. If it hits the body it leaves any species with one light melee attack left in them. On hitting the head the target will instantly die. This works against predators often as their head is pretty big. Now finally for the spear. I feel like this one would have made first if it werent for my love of the disc. The spear is a skillshot weapon that can miss often. If it does hit it is a guaranteed kill. That is it for the predator other than the fact that it is harder to knock him down and while his light atack is slower than the aliens his heavy attack is much faster. ALIEN: The alien is a more aggressive charcter in general. The alien has only its melee, to make up for this it has the most mobility in the entire game. It can climb on any surface. Its heavy attack is an insant if they are on the wall. It wont do full heavy attack damage if you dont hit them in the head. If you do manage to hit them in the head they are pretty much screwed. As it stuns and does alot of damage. A second tail will usually kill them. The alien can be very prone to dieing if they fight up too close to their target and make their approach obvious. The alien has the second most health in the game. In melee combat what they have superior to the predator is their light attack is much faster. Their heavy attack although slower stuns longer. Their finishing moves AKA grabs are usually faster. This can be an upside or a down-side depending on how you look at it, but the alien automatically regenerates health.MARINE: The marine is sterotyped as the worst character in the game. He is not. The reason his seems to be is he is very difficult although when mastered is a hell hole to deal with. The marine has the lowest health and mobility. The marine fights with guns.GUNS: Pistol: It is his weakest weapon although it has unlimited ammo.Pulse rifle: It is his auto-matic assult rifle. It is the all around weapon. It has alot of ammo its mag size being 99. Jesus. PS You also get to start with this is multiplayer when you spawn. Its secondary fire is a grenade. AKA Noob toob for cod players.Shotgun: If you have enemies that like to pounce at you instead of blocking try to hit them with this last second. The shotgun is a very up-close weapon its secondary fire is a buckshot that will stun and instakill if close enough.Sniper: My favorite weapon. If you hit all shots in the body it will three hit. Don't let that fool you into thinking its bad. Its semi automatic so this seems op to some players. The second shot will stun too. If you hit an alien or predator in the head they will be stunned so finish them with one more bullet as headshots will leave them with low enough health to die to this.Smartgun: The marines last but not least weapon. This is like a minigun except with a square on your screen that it has aimbot in. This thing is the bain of predator players. It will detect them while they are invisible. The only downsides to this weapon are having low ammo. Cant run while holding it and it takes up two weapon slots.In my oppinion this is one of the most under-rated games of all time. This game derserves so much love that it doesnt get. The only thing that ruins my fun is hackers which arent too common but you will see one of you play this enough. I want you to try this game. Its not even that expensive. To me if it were 100 dollars I would still get it. I hope you have fun in your journeys of this game! Bye bye!

												Although this game doesnt compare to the original AvP1 (Gold Edition) and AvP 2, this game is pretty much fun on its own. You get to play as three of the original species in the AvP universe: the xenomorph, the predator, and the humans. Probably the most fun I've had is playing as the Predator and sneaking up behind human and gutting them.  Shooting aliens is also very fun as the marines too.  The only thing I disliked was the fact that when you climb walls as the Alien you will get a major headache and this game lacks the CROUCH control!! Really... a FPS game that lacks crouching!?!?! Overall, this game is fun if you are a big fan of the AvP universe, the graphics are nice, and the environment is great too.  Sooo are you guys ready to "GET TO THE CHOPPPPPAAAA!!!!"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 11, 2015
												Very fun game. Granted, it is 5 years old now, it has pretty impressive graphics. Now, I've had this game for a while and never really downloaded it because I expected it to not work on my computer. I recently decided "I might as well try it" so I downloaded it, and played it. It ran perfectly. But I'm not here to talk about the Graphics, I'm here to talk about why it's fun.First impressionsWell, first thing I thought of when I loaded the game up was Metroid Prime. Why? Well the Main Menu, as well as the gameplay just kinda reminded me of it. Especially the Predator's playthrough. I still can't shake the Metroid Prime vibe it gives me, but I like it x3Now, onto the campaigns:The PredatorSo. The ultimate bounty hunter (next to Samus Aran of course) in your control. I didn't really know what to expect at first, but I went through the tutorial and was like "hey this game's pretty neat!" I liked how the predator could jump to areas (it's a bit weird that it didn't let me sometimes, but then I realized you have to be at a certain distance). The Predator has a variety of weapons at his disposal (who doesn't know that though) and has an interesting playstyle. I kept uncloaking accidently when I mean to use the Predator vision, but that's my own fault xD I eventually stopped the confusion, and managed to play the Predator alright.The MarinesNow this was the second campaign I decided to try out, because I wanted to get a feel of all the playstyles before I go through the entire Predator campaign. This was a drastic change from the Predator, mainly because you can't exactly jump around or use special vision to see your enemies. I didn't mind it though, I actually liked the "helpess" feel it kinda gave. It gave a more serious, and spooky, playstyle because you only have a flare and a flashlight to see in the dark, and although you do have a gun, and a radar, you still need to be on your toes. If you want a good "scare" (and I mean that lightly, more so creepy if anything), I'd say play as Marines.The AliensYou know the saying "Last but not least", or, "Save the best for last"? Well, I didn't intend to play the Aliens last, but the Predator just caught my eye first. When I played as The Alien, I actually got a very strong "I'm a pet dog" feel. I dunno, I found it entertaining to act as if I were the humans' Alien pet. But aside from that, the gameplay of the Alien was AWESOME. I don't know about you, but the mobility of the Alien, and knowing you're a huge threat to humans (and maybe Predators) gives me the biggest boner most excitement when I play as it. Why, you ask? Well, my reason is that the Alien is the coolest freakin' thing in the game (next to the Predator) to play as. I just love being able to climb on walls, hiss whenever I want, and crawl SUPER FREAKIN' FAST, as well as have a huge tail. I love the tail. I can't even explain anymore why I love the Alien so much, it's just my favorite one to play as. He's so fast, and so sneaky. Gotta love it.MultiplayerI know this game is 5 years old, but hey, I decided why not try the multiplayer? I searched for a lobby, and managed to find 2 other people. Yes, the multiplayer is unfortunately very very dead, BUT I do believe that if you get a bunch of friends to play with (which I have yet to do, but I really want to), you'll most likely have a great time.Anywho, I really do recommend this game, and it's actually on sale now for like $3.74, so get it while it's still cheap!! It's worth it, trust me.For any tl;dr peoplePredator
 Predator first playthrough I chose Predator is pretty cool, variety of weps, interesting playstyleMarines
 Gives "spooky/creepy" feel Almost helpess, only source of light is flare + Flashlight You have guns, but watch your backAliens
 My favorite playstyle Super freakin' agile/fast/awesome You have a very awesome tail to kill with Being a huge threat (to humans and maybe Predator) feels awesomeMultiplayer
 Ded :c Could potentially be VERY fun with friends Worth it if you have a lot of friends to play withSo yeah. That's my review of Aliens vs. Predator. Try it for yourself, see which playstyle is your favorite. :)

content:
7, 2015
												An amazing game both for campaign and the multiplayer! Works perfectly with the XBOX controller for windows and I found the controls easy to use. Game runs smoothly, though I recommend for less lag turning down the resolution. I noticed when I was playing the campaign, it would lag a bit and some enemies seemed to teleport by the time I would try to shoot them; I would end up dying because of this. The story for each campaign connects and you get 3 different views on it! I found it to be engaging and fun. An experience you will never forget!As for online, I know many people were worried about not many people playing on the servers, but when I went on there were various servers to choose from. People still play this a lot! Especially since it is on PC. If you are playing the console version, yes, the servers might be dead, but PC? That hardly seems to be a problem.If anything, join groups to find others who frequently play online. Highly recommend if you are looking for an action game with some scares in it! (Marines campaign is the scariest)

content:
y 23, 2015
												Incredibly fun game! In fact, this is my second favorite AVP game(The first being AVP2, which unfortunately isn't available on steam) The graphics are incredible and each of the three single player campaigns are quite long, and let's you choose to play as either Alien, Predator or Lunch. In fact, each is like a game in and of it's self! My favorite Campaign is the Alien campaign....it's ALWAYS the alien campaign!In fact, if I were told to find fault in the game I would be very hard pressed! The game is very well polished as far as FPS titles goes. It's very well fleshed out, and I am quite pleased! I guess though I would like to see the game more active in the online area. However I am more interested in the SP aspect of games, the Multiplayer capabilities is just an added bonus(unless it's a co-op mode...i love those).If you love Aliens(or Predator), and love a solid story driven single player experience, then I highly recommend this game! If you are only interested in Multiplayer then you might want to reconsider due to the few people who do play online.

												Very fun game. Granted, it is 5 years old now, it has pretty impressive graphics. Now, I've had this game for a while and never really downloaded it because I expected it to not work on my computer. I recently decided "I might as well try it" so I downloaded it, and played it. It ran perfectly. But I'm not here to talk about the Graphics, I'm here to talk about why it's fun.First impressionsWell, first thing I thought of when I loaded the game up was Metroid Prime. Why? Well the Main Menu, as well as the gameplay just kinda reminded me of it. Especially the Predator's playthrough. I still can't shake the Metroid Prime vibe it gives me, but I like it x3Now, onto the campaigns:The PredatorSo. The ultimate bounty hunter (next to Samus Aran of course) in your control. I didn't really know what to expect at first, but I went through the tutorial and was like "hey this game's pretty neat!" I liked how the predator could jump to areas (it's a bit weird that it didn't let me sometimes, but then I realized you have to be at a certain distance). The Predator has a variety of weapons at his disposal (who doesn't know that though) and has an interesting playstyle. I kept uncloaking accidently when I mean to use the Predator vision, but that's my own fault xD I eventually stopped the confusion, and managed to play the Predator alright.The MarinesNow this was the second campaign I decided to try out, because I wanted to get a feel of all the playstyles before I go through the entire Predator campaign. This was a drastic change from the Predator, mainly because you can't exactly jump around or use special vision to see your enemies. I didn't mind it though, I actually liked the "helpess" feel it kinda gave. It gave a more serious, and spooky, playstyle because you only have a flare and a flashlight to see in the dark, and although you do have a gun, and a radar, you still need to be on your toes. If you want a good "scare" (and I mean that lightly, more so creepy if anything), I'd say play as Marines.The AliensYou know the saying "Last but not least", or, "Save the best for last"? Well, I didn't intend to play the Aliens last, but the Predator just caught my eye first. When I played as The Alien, I actually got a very strong "I'm a pet dog" feel. I dunno, I found it entertaining to act as if I were the humans' Alien pet. But aside from that, the gameplay of the Alien was AWESOME. I don't know about you, but the mobility of the Alien, and knowing you're a huge threat to humans (and maybe Predators) gives me the biggest boner most excitement when I play as it. Why, you ask? Well, my reason is that the Alien is the coolest freakin' thing in the game (next to the Predator) to play as. I just love being able to climb on walls, hiss whenever I want, and crawl SUPER FREAKIN' FAST, as well as have a huge tail. I love the tail. I can't even explain anymore why I love the Alien so much, it's just my favorite one to play as. He's so fast, and so sneaky. Gotta love it.MultiplayerI know this game is 5 years old, but hey, I decided why not try the multiplayer? I searched for a lobby, and managed to find 2 other people. Yes, the multiplayer is unfortunately very very dead, BUT I do believe that if you get a bunch of friends to play with (which I have yet to do, but I really want to), you'll most likely have a great time.Anywho, I really do recommend this game, and it's actually on sale now for like $3.74, so get it while it's still cheap!! It's worth it, trust me.For any tl;dr peoplePredator
 Predator first playthrough I chose Predator is pretty cool, variety of weps, interesting playstyleMarines
 Gives "spooky/creepy" feel Almost helpess, only source of light is flare + Flashlight You have guns, but watch your backAliens
 My favorite playstyle Super freakin' agile/fast/awesome You have a very awesome tail to kill with Being a huge threat (to humans and maybe Predator) feels awesomeMultiplayer
 Ded :c Could potentially be VERY fun with friends Worth it if you have a lot of friends to play withSo yeah. That's my review of Aliens vs. Predator. Try it for yourself, see which playstyle is your favorite. :)

content:
, 2014
												Violence can't buy my love.Aliens vs. Predator  it's a decent game for me, it starts off with an undoubthly good setting presenting itself as a high production Aliens and Predator game that the fans have been waiting for a very long time.However that's only half the reality, the game starts getting boring when you start noticing there's not many more than the wonderful graphics and scenarios, as a matter of fact, the scenarios trascend to all three campaigns as beign the same (this beign marine, alien, and predator) If there's anything good to be said it's that the campaigns tends to have it's moments and keep itself off from trying to be pretencious and overboard it's own expectations.The problem it's that the game it's extremely repetitive, this making it fell off a pattern that doesn't go nowhere rather than just force the player to keep playing through moments that he already been in. Overall it just wasn't a fun or even enjoyable ride, it sure keeps it's moments the executions from the predator and the marine campaign are something definitley worth your time but the little to no worthwhile details don't seem to cut it for me.The price is also excessive, this game should be ten dollars, maybe seven, But fiftheen? For a game like this is just not worth your time, however i like it and this is why im giving it a recommendation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2014
												A side from the "bad" story in single player, it's a blast in multiplayer. Well if you're not a noob that is. Anyways great combat system, acts like rock paper scissors in a sense. Marines have a long distance advantage, Xenomorphs get the melee advantage, while predators are a combination of the two. Everything balances out in combat, cept the xenomorphs randomly walk on walls during combat. Other than the bad story and difficult controls of the xenomorphs. Great Game! 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2015
												Bought it on sale for 4 bucks. This game is great and very fun. 3 campaignsMarine, Xenomorph, and PredatorPros: Fun and challenging story (especially on Nightmare difficulty. No checkpoints)Each campaign has a unique play style. Marine is surviving from xeno attacks, Alien's and Prdeator's have a stealthy feelMultiplayer is very fun, especially with friendsCons:The campaigns are fairly short. About 5-6 missions each classYou'll occasionally find that one casul in multiplayer that's a hacker teleporting around the mapSome game modes are harder to find a match for than others8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2015
												This is one of my favourites games I've ever played, very nice graphics and the game it's from 2010. The thing that disappointed me is the campaign from all the 3 species.. The Alien one is short, ended like in almost 2 hours.. and one more thing, the mutliplayer is dead.. it's so sad that the game is not played anymore by some people, at least you can play with friends. I really recommend it, but the campaign is short... all you can do after you beat it is inviting some friends to play multiplayer with you (it's very fun) or search for people to play together.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2012
												The DEMO does NOT do this game justice!  This game is very fluid in feel, the plot is simple enough but you know what you're getting with an AVPVM game.  It's held to it's origins pitting the three races against each other in a horror-sci-fi setting and has a great scary feel to it.  The game has hours and hours of playtime.  I may be biased, as an AVP fan since AVP1 (and before, through comics), but I would give this game an 85/100.

10, 2015
												While AVP doesn't exactly do anything special in a first person shooter it still is a lot of fun. Every faction has it's own unique gameplay style.  The game is a bit more than average and $15 is a pretty reasonable price, but if you can grab it on sale for about $5 it would be a solid buy. The only con is that the multiplayer is practically dead except for about 3 game lobbies. Oh btw if anyone was wondering... PREDATOR CAN KICK ALIEN'S BUTT ANYDAY! HE'LL â¥â¥â¥â¥ BOTH ALIENS AND MARINES WITH HIS GADGETS AND STEALTH! FFFFFFFFFFFUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 11, 2013
												Aliens vs Predator was a blast with not one but three story modes and a great multiplayer. When playing the alien story mode you get to play as the mighty Xenomorph, bitting and slashing predators and humans in brutal ways. When play the Predator in the predator story mode you to kill aliens and humans with hi-tech equipment like the laser gun and the claw. In the Marine story mode it mainly consist of marines vs aliens and not much of the predators.  For people which like Call of Duty and first person shooters, the marine mode is for you. If you like Adventure games or action games the alien or predator mode will suit you.6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
12, 2014
												Why does this game get so much crap? It's pretty amazing! There may not be a huge number of campaign missions but each level is at least a 20 minute ride of excitement! The gameplay is immersive and you actually feel like you are walking in the shoes/claws of each of the species! Each of the stories intertwine into climactic battles of their own and theres a lot of hidden collectibles!And fyi, the multiplayer is definately NOT DEAD! Plenty of people still play it, and I can't blame them! It's a multiplayer experience unlike anything else! GET THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 9, 2014
												While this latestet iteration of the Alien Vs. Predator franchise is perhaps not nearly so terrifying insofar as playing a human is concerned, it moves fowards in leaps and bounds towards granting players a true feeling of being a predator and being an alien. The abilities, atmosphere and sound effects associated with playing the two non terrestrial races gives a satisfyingly powerful feeling while still requiring careful attention to avoid sudden and immediate death.There is very little to mention beyond the fact that fans of the AvP franchise will be pleasently satisfied by the experience provided here, at least on the surface.The big downside of the game however, is found in it's length and a multiplayer component that is terribly one sided toward predator players who have skill.If you're looking for a lasting and challenging experience within the AvP universe, this probaby isnt it since the only real challenge lies in learning certain encounters, but if you want to indulge the hunter within and claim some trophies, then pick this one up while it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												This version of the Aliens vs Predator franchise is definitely the best I've seen so far, though I still haven't tried Alien Isolation, which is the kind of content the Alien franchise should be producing, for both film and game.This game brings you into the alternate universe brought about in the Dark Horse comic book series, that pits the James Cameron's technological Colonial Marines against Ridley Scott and H.R. Giger's Aliens, along with Stan Winston's Predator (character and costume design anyway).Pros:::: Graphics are great, supporting D3D11 features, characters and environments really come to life...::: Sound and foley is emersive::: Story line is well written as well, involving a separate campaign storyline for each species including characters from the movies (Lance Henrikson's Weyland)::: Multiplayer is fun and can be an exceptional experience depending upon which characters you play as::: Multiplayer maps created from the movie locations, including the Nostromo, Fury 161 and Hadley's Hope (the colony on LV-426)::: Separate mouse sensitivity for both the X and Y axis::: Close combat system for those "close encounters"::: Skirmish (both single and multiplayer) mode that pits a species against an onslaught of the Aliens which can be quite fun::: The menus have a real Weyland-Yutani feel to them and are very well doneCons:::: Multiplayer can be a little bit unbalanced depending upon which species you play::: Some of the situations in the marine campaign can be very challenging comparitively to the other species::: Controls can take some getting used toThe multiplayer activity for this title has died down substantially but is still available so you might need to "hunt" for players to hunt in the game.The graphics and environments are very detailed and can be lead to claustrophobia while playing. You'll be looking over your shoulder quite often in this one if you're a marine or predator. If you're the alien, well the ai characters will spend lots of time looking over their shoulders and you can drop onto them from any surface.There's been talk of a new movie that might open up the story line from between Aliens and Alien 3, with Ellen Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) and Corporal Hicks (Michael Biehn) working together once again to thwart the spread of the Alien species and Weyland-Yutani from their mandate to weaponize the alien creatures.This title falls in part way in the Aliens universe and part way into the Predators universe. If you like the film franchise (either Alien or Predator or the combined Aliens vs Predator) then this is will be enjoyable even if just for the single player campaigns. Good as an FPS whether you are into the movies or not. Very intense if you like feeling panicked and running for your life.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 15, 2014
												Amazing recreation of a classic game brought back to life with new technology and better resources. The game offers you mult segmented parts where you play between Marine, Alien, and Predator stories. Each segment may or maynot be tied into each other but you can play on as one character through all the way or switch between each character between missions. First person controls are great and all actions and aesthetics are a perfect match to the movies. aliens can cling to ceilings and bleed corrosive blood, Marines have motion detectors and flares to help locate threats, and the Predator has his multi functional mask and futuristic arsenal. Overall its a revamp of a classic that adds depth that newer games offer. The ambiance of a dark hallway can actually become a dark threat and a predator feels powerful but still outgunned. A must have for fans of either series!

content:

												First off, the game is amazing, i would hope that another game like this would be made again or at least remaster this one. The game tells the story of three species on an alien plane: The Humans, The Aliens, and The Predators. This game was perfecty mixed with elements of action, strategy, and stealth. It requires you to play differently for every species. For humans, it requires you to stay alive using nothing but a recon, flash light, and what ever traces of ammo scatered around the world. As Aliens, it requires you to use stealth and carefuly plan your attacks to get passed motion detectors and a large amount of guards and Predators. And as the Predators, it requires you to kill the humans and rid them of your planet while trying to fight away hoardes of Alien swarms. This game is great and has an amazing story that arches into each different species. The only bad thing is the online community is dead. So, i recommend you and a friend get the game in order to play online.

content:
y 18, 2016
												AVP (2010) has nice graphics, good sound design, solid atmosphere, and an interwoven story for Human, Xenomorph and Predator species spread across three campaigns.  The campaigns can all be beaten in about 10-15 hours of play total - give or take some hours based on your proficiency and desire for achievement hunting.  And it has difficulty settings, xp for rankings, and blah blah blah...  The story isn't bad, but it really only serves as an excuse to move you through each of the rather linear mission areas.  Every species receives communication from a leader that sends them from objective to objective until the mission area is complete and you can move onto the next one.  The story environs allow you to experience the inside of a hive, a colony base, and an ancient Predator pyramid amongst ruins in a tropical jungle.  You'll encounter several variations of Xenomorphs,  Predators, and Androids - SPOILER:  They all want to kill you.As each of the species have different abilities - the playstyle for each is completely different.  Xenomorphs can climb on almost all surfaces, leap at enemies (also vents), claw at enemies, whip them with their tail, and bite into their heads.  They can also "harvest" enemies by grabbing them and allowing a facehugger to attach.  Xenomorphs specialize in stealth and speed and to that end they can hide in vents, crawl through tight spaces, destroy lights which helps them hide in the dark, and hiss to lure enemies to their (tasty) demise.  Xenomorphs can see fine in the dark and they can see the auras of enemies (even through walls), so long as they are not too far away.  They can regenerate health, provided they aren't taking damage.  The Xenomorphs have the shortest (or quickest) campaign, it seemed, but also the most fun.  The Predators specialize in gadgets.  They can cloak which is good for disguising their presence from a distance, but they can't sneak up on humans from behind like Xenomorphs can, and they can be seen even while cloaked by the Xenomorphs, or if they get too close to humans and androids.  Stepping into water also decloaks the pred, as does interacting with elements in the game.  As the Predator campaign progresses they unlock (find) new weapons and an extra view style.  Predators have two razor claws on each forearm to melee with.  They can also get the shoulder cannon, prox mines, disc, and combi stick.  The shoulder cannon produces some splash damage, but a direct hit can kill most humans and xenos.  Using it causes you to decloak though and also drains the limited energy you have, which can only be replenished by finding power sources.  The prox mines can be dropped and remotely detonated, but to be honest, I never used them.  The disc is good for range attacks - you guide the disc with a laser sight and it returns.  A careful aim can take a head off.  The combi stick is the most lethal weapon in your arsenal, provided you aim carefully.  A direct hit will kill humans, xenos, and androids.  The Predator can also leap pretty high/far using a mechanic called "focus", which also helps point out things in the environment you might not otherwise see.  The Predator has a "normal" human vision mode, a heat vision mode (only good for spotting humans and androids), and sometime midway through the campaign or so you gain a "gray" vision mode that allows you to spot Xenomorphs (to the exclusion of other enemies).  The Predator also can zoom in from afar using any mode of vision.  They heal using shards - they can carry 3 at a time.  You feel the most badass as the Predator.Humans (Marines) have it the toughest.  They're an easy, doughy, more meltable target for the other species.  They have a motion tracker, sure, but it's really limited in it's usefulness.  They have a sidearm, but it's really not the weapon of choice when being swarmed by Xenos or charged by a Predator.  They can get the pulse rifle which fires bullets and has a limited capacity grenade launcher.  They can use a shotgun, which is very deadly at close range, and a sniper rifle that's deadly at long range.  I found the sniper rifle to be a pretty useless weapon - good for picking off still targets, but not the aliens.  The best part of the human arsenal is the smartgun, but you're limited on it's availability and ammo, and are forced to drop your main weapon when picking it up (humans can only carry two weapons aside from the sidearm).  For some reason the marines don't get the night vision they had in both the movie and the previous AVP games.  This to me is a sore spot.  They do get flares they can toss, but they are, at best, impractical.  While you can putter your way through the darker areas of the singleplayer campaign putting up with this limitation, it becomes a severe handicap in dark multiplayer games against the other two species.  The humans have 3 health bars.  They can regenerate health in a bar provided they aren't taking damage.  However, if a bar is completely emptied it doesn't regenerate.  In order to fully heal then they need to use a health stim - they can carry 3 at a time.  The human campaign felt the longest to me (probably had something to do with all the dying I did).Control-wise I had issues with all three species.  The controls are at times stiff, clumsy, non-intuitive, and downright frustrating.  Part of the problem, I think, is that the game was clearly designed for controller fondling console gamers first and foremost.  It explains the wanky mechanics, the constant handholding you sense as you play, the strictly linear flow of the missions, and the god-awful item hunt to unlock masturbatory achievements.  The idea is these are 3 species fighting for survival against one another, so why am I expected to waste time snooping around for stupid hidden items that serve neither the plot or your survival?The Marine feels like his boots are made of lead.  He's slow, not particularly responsive, he can barely jump - he can't even crouch behind cover for blueberry muffin's sake!!!  WTH?  He can climb onto waist high crates and stuff, but there are only one or two places in the entire campaign where that's necessary.The Xenomorphs are faster and more agile, but you will often find yourself stuck on surfaces struggling to get off, disoriented by the unpredictability of it's movement mechanics when going from one surface to another, or fighting to get things squarely into view so you can leap into, use an interactive element, or bite into some jerks head.The Predator may fall somewhere between.  He's faster than humans, but not xenos, but he also can't crouch *sigh*.  He can leap high and far, but the mechanics in doing so is more complicated than it needed to be.Multiplayer is where this game should really shine and unfortunately it's a bust.  The game is heavily weighed against the Marines.  So, IF you can find a server to play on, all of the regulars will be either Aliens or Predators.  First off, the Predators and Xenomorphs can one-hit kill the Marines, and because both the Preds and the Xenos can leap long distances, move fast, and track you based on vision - you won't even know what happened half the time.  Remember, Marines don't get night vision, and the tracker is completely useless against opponents that can move so quick you're dead before you even register the blip.  If you're looking for an AVP universe game then this is decent, though I'd still recommend AVP Classic 2000 over this game.  To be honest, I'd recommend Alien Trilogy, Aliens:  Colonial Marines, and Alien: Isolation over this, but they don't have Predators *tear*.  The production values are all there, but the end result fell short of expectation.  Recommended if you are a fan of the franchise or are in desperate need of a decent singleplayer FPS game.

												Ever since I was a kid, both "Aliens" and the "Predator" used to both scare and fascinate me. As a fan of both, I just could not keep myself from buying this game. Which is awesome. Amazing graphics (even though it was released in 2010), fairly interesting single-player campaign story, great and intense atmosphere, a variety of characters, locations, and weapons, and of course - Multiplayer !Oh yes, Multiplayer! And guess what, you can play as either the Marines, the Predators, and even Aliens ! Choose you'r side and hop right in. There are a lot of great multiplayer game-modes. Like the "Infestation" for example. Where one marine is infected (an Alien) hunts down the others. Infecing them as well until there is just One-man-Standing. Or there is Survival, or the good-ol' Deathmatch.Anyway, lots of fun. Plenty of decapitations and gore. One of the best games in the franchise.10/10

content:
er 27, 2013
												A great unexpected movie-game. This puts a whole new type of immersion into first person shooters, to be able to feel that fear of your foe and not always knowing where they are, or when they are about to perform a finishing move on you. The game runs, looks, feels, and plays great. Definitely not what I would have expected from a movie game, it was definitely a step up for that genre, and put a much more hefty, positive definition of that category of games. The game utilizes the storyline and multiplayer very well rewarding the player as they continue to play which is a great addition all games must have but not all do, so that was very well though out.  Overall a game like this was never expected but was hoped for, and was made. And we all enjoy it more than we thought we would for it's new twist on first person shooting games, a twist absolutely for the best.

												A good reimagining of the 1999 classic. Good graphics & great sound make for a few hours of fun gameplay. Although each individual campaign is fairly short, combined (and I do suggest playing all three), the game is the same length of most FPSs. Although the storylines are quite linear, they blend into one another to create a wholistic picture of what's happening. Each species also feel very different, allowing the player to really emmerce themselves in any particular campaign. Allround, well worth playing, especially if you're a fan of the previous two games... or any of the movies.

content:
ry 17
												Played the literal crap out of this game since in came out. I used to be impressed by it until I explored every glitch and fault of the game mechanics, the rock paper scissor type of melee and how you can it be abused. It seems the developers did not bother to give a second look at their product or hear the community's requests. As they did with the '99  original Rebellion game, they chose to ignore some of the most iconic sounds, whilst having full access to FOX's movie sound database, but didn't bother to use them (my biggest gripe with the game). I had to rely on Mods in order to make up for it. The pulse rifle literally sounds like sh*t. The mods make it sound like the movie because it gradually cycles through multiple pitches of that ionic sound. I ended up replacing the sound for the smart gun as well, the shoulder cannon, predator vision/cycle, predator taunt, predator idle, heal, trophy and many more...The in game player models are fairly accurate and detailed, unfortunately the same cannot be said about the textures. Everything is bland and lifeless, and all the shaders are glossy, all glowing or looking wet even if not required to be.In trying to balance the three characters in the game some mistakes were made.... The alien sounds like it's got army boots while trying to move around and stalk someone, plus it makes dumb idling noises which have nothing to do with it's nature.They interlaced the three campaigns which is not necessary. The Alien campaign is the most lacking and boring to play.The multiplayer still suffers from glitches and unbalanced play, not to talk about casual cheaters which nobody bothers to ban.Final verdict 6/10 if you are a fan of the franchise and have the nostalgia of the 1999 version of Avp.

												The campaign is short and boring, but the real fun is in MP. The animations of fights are made really nicely and I've really enjoyed unmerciful battles. The best mod is classic DM, where fight all the 3 races. Mainly on the map Refinery, there is a hell if you play on some full server. I preferred to play with a marine, but the other races are funny as well. Predators are easier to learn because to play well with the Alien is seriously hard. I recommend this game to the fans of AvP series, but I think that beginners in the universe can have a fun too because the game is very underrated.

												Let me preface this with the important highlight that ~Multiplayer is DEAD~Now that that's out the way... We have a slightly spooky romp of 4 hours or so through the Marine campaign where your "IS IT IN THE VENTS OMG" fear of one alien is replaced with lets-kill-a-hundred-of-these-every-level after the initial 10 minutes.The Alien campaign sucks, tearing 360Â° around the environment at lightning speeds is fun on F-Zero X, not in a FPS while you're being shot at while completely disorientated.Predator has potential but his storyline is one hour long and you never get the chance to really fight the swarthes of enemies his weaponry was just begging to tear up.A dissapointing game that is worth <Â£4.99 of your time, the DX11 specular bump mapping does make for some shiny skinned aliens though I will admit.

content:
y 19
												Well, this was an unexpected little slice of awesome.The first time I actually encountered this particular game was via a review of it courtesy of Yahtzee Croshaw (AKA Zero Punctuation). And I have to say, I'm very glad I decided to satisfy my burning interest in this game.Aliens VS Predator is a game set in (You guessed it) the universe of Ridley Scott's Alien, with the Predators also being featured heavily in this universe. The campaign in the game is divided into three; One for the Marines (which is essentially just Generic Dudebro Filler for all the CoD lovers out there), one for the Aliens/Xenomorphs (which has much more stealth and facebiting), and one for the Predator(s) (which is a combination of the two, minus the facebiting). Each of these campaigns is linked chronologically, with the Alien campaign becoming the starting point, and the reason for the marines turning up in the first place. However, the predators have also turned up since the ever idiotic Weyland Yutani Corporation has unearthed a Predator Pyramid, and open it, unleashing an energy nullifying wave. This not only allows the Aliens to escape, but alerts the predators. The rest I'll let you figure out yourself.As mentioned, the Marine campaign is essentially just a standard sci-fi military shooter with horror elements, and the gameplay is so generic you've likely already seen it before in most shooters; you have your infinite ammo pistol, your shotgun, your machine gun, and to make it seem like you are infact in the Alien world, you have an Alien tracking smartgun.As for the Aliens however, their gameplay is completely different. Success in Alien levels relies on two things: Your mobility and your Stealth abilities. Since you're a Xenomorph, you can crawl through vents, across walls, ceilings etc at a lightning speed, making you incredibly difficult to hit when escaping enemies. Your speed is a double-edged sword however, since if you're not mentally prepared first, you may get a tad queasy; the speed at which you go at and the sometimes automatic wall crawling can be very disorientating. You will likely not notice after a little while however, as in comes the second element of the Aliens; stealth. Now unfortunately, rather than hunting Sigourney Weaver, you're hunting an organised Marine Corp. Or at least that's what they call themselves. More often than not you'll be presented with a room/area full of Dudebro marines, all spouting out repeating (and VERY irritating) lines. You'll then have to pick them off one by one, and if you try and take on multiple marines at once, you will likely get filled with bullet holes for you trouble. Because of this, I do feel that the stealth is rather like the Batman Arkham series of games; you have to take out your enemies slowly and with patience, or you'll be punished severely. However, to make up for this, the killing animations you have access to are incredibly satisfying, if not very f**king brutal; you can stab people in the back with your tail, rip people heads off, expose people to the wonders of facehuggers, or just go all Vlad the Impaler on them with your tail instead. Just remember to clean the s**tstains afterwards.And for the final slice of gameplay: The Predator. In my humble opinion, I feel this is the best of the three campaigns, since it manages to successfully balance Combat and Stealth and ensure the two aren't intertwined when they don't need to be. Not only this, but the gadgets the predator has access to are the most interesting in the game by far; you can mess about with the typical claw gadgets, a combi stick/spear, the plasma projector, a Captain America shield esque saw blade boomerang, and some old-but-gold mines. When you play as a predator, (similarly to the Alien) there will be two main aspects of gameplay you will need: Strategy and (again) Stealth. The strategy comes into play because you'll have to ensure you have some form of battle plan before you go charging in headfirst and get killed by some smarmy chucklef**k with a shotgun. You remember how I mentioned the stealth in this game is similar to the stealth used in Batman Arkham? The similarities are much more prevalent with the predator, who has heat vision, and even a jumping and vantage point system similar to the grappling used in Batman Arkham. However, unlike Batman, you don't leave your prey alive. You collect their heads. You blow them into cartilage with a plasma projector, or just sneak up on them and stick claw gadgets in their back and lift them at least one metre in the air whilst yelling like a caveman who just beat a sabre cat in a fist fight. However, whilst most of the Predator campaign (and gameplay) is very fun and pleasantly challenging in areas, the final boss for this particular campaign is complete and utter horses**t, and nothing else. This particular enemy is not only incredibly aggressive towards you, deals a s**t ton of damage that you cannot block or avoid (unlike with other enemies and bosses the predator encounters), and is also very VERY agile. Agile to the point of you being completely unable to hit it without using mines, which slow you down whilst you arm them and leave you open to an attack. Did I mention the high aggression and high damage? To top it all off, the area where you fight contains destructible platforms, lava that kills you instantly and sticks you back at the start, and also a checkpoint that will stick this c**t right back at full health once you die. There's no checkpoint once he'd down at half health, just anger and foaming mouths. The only upside of this fight is that your energy (which you rely on to help you charge your mines and plasma projector) recharges quickly, a quality that isn't shared with the rest of the campaign. However, this is essentially p***ing in the wind with regards to this bossfight, and doesn't help bury the other s**tty aspects.All in all, a slightly flawed but very enjoyable game that is well worth your time, regardless of whether or not you've actually watched the films this game was based on.8/10

content:
r 26, 2014
												This game is VERY good, but many people seem to dislike the shortness and there seems to be general confusion about the time line and exactly how MANY predators get deployed to handle the xeno outbreak, and why so many if they are the "best" fighters. There is also a major plot hole that messes with the entire predator story line. You see in the second mission of the predator you visit the hive and it has already been burned down. Here is where a lot of confusion comes in, as you see by the end of the aliens missions aliens cannot live/function without a queen YET you spend all the predator missions fighting aliens who have NO queen which creates not only a paradox but also a massive plot hole.  The next problem is the humans, not just the marines but all of them. They all do stupid stuff and say "JEE I WONDER WHAT CAN GO WRONG?" and these idiots always end up dead. The best example is the distraction function of the predator "oh whats that? all my squad is dead? well even though i know this for a fact i'm going to walk to where i heard voices" see the idiocy in this? The stupidity is unbearable if you are trying to play as a marine because the AI for the marines is that of a very stupid 2 year old. Not to mention anyone who has ever tried to harness the power of xenomorphs gets stupider and more moronic each time.  On a gameplay level this game holds up, except the xenomorph because that can be disorienting but it will never be as bad as classic 2000. The predator is very fun to play as but despite how bad the marine AI is they can turn you from a big bad murder machine to a pile of swiss cheese in no time. Which would have to be another problem for me, the guns are not as powerful when you use them, but when any other marine uses the guns they tear you apart. The reason i worded it as "tear you apart" is because they cannot do anything when you play as a marine, but the moment you switch to alien or predator they shoot up some kind of meth and become super man.  This AVP game is also a huge improvment from the classic 2000 in many ways. If you tried playing AVP 2000 and found it too confusing, this game is dumbed down and easier to play for the most part. Not to mention that there are HUDS that give you proper directions instead of "go find the switch that i won't tell you exactly where it is, but i can give you an estimation of about where it might be." making it easier to get about the place.   Over all this game is worth buying and playing through a few times. It has only a small handfull of bugs that never got out of hand or even bothered me that much, the AI is not to bad for the most part, and it is fun to play as the Alien and Predator if you love having superiority and it's fun to play the marines if you like the horror feel. This game lands an 8/10 on my personal rating.

												While it's a little too easy to perform sync kills on players in multiplayer, the single-player campaigns are great and extremely atmospheric. I'd even go so far as to say that the games are better than the "Alien" "Predator" movies themselves. Of the three races, however, the Xenomorph (my favorite) lost the most in this updated version. It's more easily  countered by the Colonial Marine and the Predator, and since it only has melee options for combat, you have to get your head around playing in a more conservative style as the Xenomorph.On the plus side, the graphics are a huge improvement over the first "Aliens vs. Predator", and the eye-candy is nothing to discount. I would definitely recommend the single-player campaigns, especially as an introduction to the controls, mastery of which you'll definitely need for multiplayer. The Colonial Marine campaign was especially well-done in terms of instilling a sense of fear and anxiety for your Marine's safety.
